speaker: Groundskeeper
lines: A lantern rocks on a nail; its flame holds its breath between gusts.
The groundskeeper's coat is patched with the same cloth as his shroud-sacks.
'Salt the thresholds, sing the names, don't look back,' he recites without looking up.
He pours tea the color of old coins and hands you a cup that remembers other hands.
'If a bell rings twice, run. If it rings once, listen. If it doesn't ring, worry.'
He points his hook toward the crypts. 'Family debts live longer than family pride.'
'If a shadow asks your name, ask it why it needs to know.'
He smiles like a trench and returns to trimming the yew.

choices.text: Pocket a measure of salt from his bench.
Thank him and descend to the crypts.
